thread.title: Brexit-backing MP says he doesn't trust EU negotiators 'as far as I could throw them'

author: Jonathan Walker
title: Brexit-backing MP says he doesn't trust EU negotiators 'as far as I could throw them'
text:
How the North East voted - in full
Mr Campbell also criticised the EU's freedom of movement rules, which currently make it easy for workers from EU countries to come to the UK.
He said: "All that immigration has been in this country is cheap labour. We have to be honest about that. People have been brought in, especially on the farms, as cheap labour."
The House of Lords has been debating the proposed Brexit deal and Liberal Democrat peer Lord Shipley, a former leader of Newcastle City Council , said he backs a second referendum or People's Vote. Read More How will North East MPs vote on Brexit? Only one will back Theresa May's under-fire deal
He said: "All versions of Brexit will make us poorer.
"I have concluded that we need to ask the British people whether they still want to leave the EU now that they know the cost of Brexit or whether they prefer to stay in, with all the advantages of the customs union, the single market and membership of European programmes. How the North East voted in the EU Referendum in June 2016
Newcastle: Remain 65,404 (50.7%); Leave 63,598 (49.3%)
Sunderland: Remain 51,930 (38.7%); Leave 82,394 (61.3%)
North Tyneside: Remain 52,873 (46.63%); Leave 60,589 (53.37%)
Gateshead: Remain 44,429 (43.2%); Leave 58,529 (56.8%)
South Tyneside: Remain 30,014 (38%); Leave 49,065 (62%)
Durham: Remain 113,521 (42.5%); Leave 153,877 (57.5%)
Northumberland: Remain 82,022 (46%); Leave 96,699 (54%)
"I accept that this would require a peopleâ€™s vote, and I will support that."
Two North East Labour MPs have confirmed again that they will definitely vote against Mrs May's deal. Read More UK can cancel decision to leave the EU, European Court of Justice says
Kevan Jones, MP for North Durham , and Grahame Morris, MP for Easington, had both said previously that they will be voting against it.
However, some websites suggested last week that they might vote in favour. The MPs have said again that will vote against it. Kevan Jones, Labour MP for North Durham (Image: PA)
Meanwhile, Mrs May has suggested that MPs would have the power to stop the backstop coming into effect.
The move is likely to be seen as a bid to bolster flagging support ahead of a crunch Commons vote on her EU withdrawal deal on Tuesday - a showdown the PM made clear she would not postpone. Read More
